statement.p: Arrange the following functions in order, such that any function higher on the list dominates any function lower on the list.

solution.p: We show a few representative calculations.

First we compare \ln(x) to \sqrt{x}. By L'Hôpital's Rule and some simplifying algebra,
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt{x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\frac{1}{x}}{\frac{1}{2x^{1/2}}} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{2x^{1/2}}{x} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{2}{x^{1/2}} . Thus, it follows that
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt{x}} = 0 , and hence \sqrt{x} dominates \ln(x).

Similarly, we can show that \sqrt[3]{x} dominates \ln(x). By L'Hôpital's Rule and some simplifying algebra,
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt[3]{x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\frac{1}{x}}{\frac{1}{3 x^{2/3}}} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{3x^{2/3}}{x} . Since \frac{x^{2/3}}{x} = x^{-1/3}, it follows that
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt[3]{x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{x^{1/3}} = 0
